Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) carries the genetic information needed to sustain life via unique combinations of four different nucleobases (adenine, guanine, thymine, and cytosine) and has a double-stranded structure with its nucleobases shielded by the phosphate backbone groups.
1 Two of these nucleobases, adenine and guanine, are purines, with a double-ring structure. The other two, thymine and cytosine, are pyrimidines containing a single-ring structure.
